large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Animals with Their Families

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (care, support).
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What is one way animal parents care for their babies?
Read for enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words; Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to count with one-to-one correspondence.
Ask children to match Activity Cards with Number Cards.
Challenge children to count the same animals in a different order.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is there an animal in this book? How does this animal act?
Can you pretend to be an animal? What animal will you be?
Can you draw a family of animals? How many babies are in this family?
Can you write about a baby animal?
What materials can you use to create a baby animal?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word topi?
Can you use blocks to build an animal family? How many family members will you make?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Animals with Their Families

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder ask and answer questions and introduce vocabulary (conversation).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Baby Animals with Their Families.
Read closely to ask and answer questions about animal babies and their families using the book’s pictures.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to ten objects.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Focus attention (self-regulation).
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to ask questions about baby animal pictures.
Help children answer questions, focus their attention, and use their imagination.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What question could you ask about this book?
Can you pretend to be an animal in a herd? What conversations will you have with the other members of your herd?
Can you make a herd of ten topi? How many will be baby topi?
Can you write a conversation between two elephants?
Can you make an animal family? Why did you choose those colors?
Can you find three things in the room that start with the same sound as sloth?
Can you build a pride of five lions? How can you show which ones are cubs?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Animals with Their Families

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share an addition strategy, act out subtraction, and introduce vocabulary (same, fewer).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Baby Animals with Their Families and asking the guiding question, What is one way that animals keep their babies safe?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review operations.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use matching or counting to compare the size of one group to another, using the words “more,” “less,” “greater than,” “fewer,” “same,” or equal.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn more or share information; Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to use concrete models for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set of 5.
Guide children to make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set of 5.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you added one animal to that book, how many would there be?
How could you act like an animal we’ve read about?
Can you draw two animals? How many animals can you add to make five?
Can you write about an animal family that has three babies?
Can you draw a number story about an animal family that has two babies?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the name of your favorite animal?
Can you build an animal family that has fewer babies than adults?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Animals With Their Families by Suzi Eszterhas. Text and photographs copyright © 2019 Suzi Eszterhas. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Owlkids Books Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio.”
Big Book: Baby Animals with Their Families

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to reflect on learning and introduce vocabulary (chicks, shelter).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Baby Animals with Their Families and The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio.”
Read interactively and connect to this week’s essential question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use matching or counting to compare the size of one group to another, using the words “more,” “less,” “greater than,” “fewer,” “same,” or equal; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information; Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to count a given number of “chicks” from a set of 10.
Guide children to compare groups and determine which group contains fewer “chicks.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think about that book?
Why did you decide to act like that animal instead of a different animal?
If you have five animals in your animal family, and two leave to find food, how many are left?
Can you write a story comparing two animal families?
What would be the safest shelter for a chick? Can you build it?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of pio? Can you write that letter?
How can you make your shelter stronger so it won’t fall over?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Animals With Their Families by Suzi Eszterhas. Text and photographs copyright © 2019 Suzi Eszterhas. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Owlkids Books Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Animals with Their Families

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to science, play an addition game, and introduce vocabulary (predators).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What is one way people help their babies live, learn, and grow?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns
Ask and answer questions in order to learn more or share information; Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a growing number of theme words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “Write a story about your favorite animal family.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you want to read next?
Pretend to be an animal no one has ever seen. How many babies will you have? How will you care for them?
I have 1 fish. How many more do I need to make a group of 5?
Can you write a story about a family of made-up animals?
Can you draw a new animal family that no one has ever seen before?
Make up a name for a pretend animal and spell it. What sounds do you hear?
What ideas do you have for building a home for an animal family? What materials will you use?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use a variety of words to describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Use a variety of words to describe.
Use a large speaking vocabulary.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Demonstrate that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Recognize and create patterns.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Operations: Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects. (TX.V.B.1); Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set. (TX.V.B.2)

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
